   cancer, now with respiratory distress and septic shock.

 MULTI LUMEN - START [**2109-3-26**] 08:00 AM

   akinesis of her anteroseptal wall and severe HK of the remaining
   segments c/w largre recent anterior infarct.
   -A thoracic surgery consult was obtained given SQ emphysema and
   inability to place both NGT and OGT, pharyngoscopy showed 2-3cm linear
   horizontal tear in hypopharynx to right of midline. Recommended abx as
   we are doing, daily CXR, will drain if fluid collection forms, possible
   EGD at some point to r/o esophageal injury.
   -PICC line from OSH removed and tip sent for culture.
   -Bronchoscopy by IP showed no tracheal/bronchial tear, also saw linear
   mucosal injury in posterior hypopharynx.
   -CT neck revealed pharyngeal swelling but no clots or further extension
   of SQ emphysema.
   -Patient placed on steroids, bolused 2 L IVF, 1 unit FFP. Evidence of
   focal DVT in the right cephalic vein. KUB negative. Unable to get CT
   abdomen due to no peripheral access and no NGT/OGT. EJ attempt failed.
   -ETT tube in right mainstem, repeat CXR at level of clavicles
   -Weaned levophed from 0.2 to 0.08, decreased RR to 12 on vent with AM
   ABG

   Imaging: CT Neck:
   IMPRESSION:
   1. No definite evidence of airway narrowing. Moderate edema in the
   posterior oropharynx, without discrete fluid collection or abscess.
   2. Endotracheal tube tip positioned near the ostium of the right main
   stem
   bronchus. Tube should be withdrawn for more optimal positioning.
   3. Extensive subcutaneous emphysema, predominantly in the right neck,
   though
   the exact site of injury, is not visualized on non-contrast CT.
   4. Unchanged moderate bilateral pleural effusions and atelectasis.
   ------------------------------
   Echo:
   The left atrium is elongated. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and
   cavity size are normal. There is severe regional left ventricular
   systolic dysfunction with akinesis of the septum and anterior wall and
   severe hypokinesis of the rest of the segments. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 20-25 %).
   Right ventricular chamber size is normal. with mild global free wall
   hypokinesis. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The
   ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are
   mildly thickened. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral
   valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild to moderate ([**11-21**]+) mitral
   regurgitation is seen. The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests a
   restrictive filling abnormality, with elevated left atrial pressure.
   The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Moderate [2+]
   tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary artery
   systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. There is an
   anterior space which most likely represents a fat pad.
   --------------------
   USD:
   IMPRESSION: Evidence of focal DVT in the right cephalic vein
   surrounding an
   indwelling PICC. Thrombus does not extend into the axillary, subclavian
   or IJ veins.
   Microbiology: BCx: NGTD
   UCx: NGTD
   Catheter Tip: NGTD
   Sputum: NGTD
   Assessment and Plan
 CARDIOMYOPATHY, OTHER
   Assessment and Plan
   79F with COPD, CAD, a fib, lung cancer, now with respiratory distress
   and septic shock now with clear evidence of recent cardiac event.
   .
   # Respiratory failure
 Likely resulting from septic shock (below).
   Acute episode of sob at rehab concerning for PNA versus PE (CTA
   negative) vs. CHF (mild chf on exam).  She does not have an obvious
   infiltrate on the CXR.
   - Intubated after a complicated course at OSH (pharyngeal laceration).
   - Currently with excellent ABG 7.4/37/146 on current vent settings,
   awaiting AM RISBI.  Probably could tolerate pressure support trial
   today but given complicated intubation may be preferable to wait until
   swelling resolves so as not to loose airway.
   - Nebs given history of COPD
   - No e/o significant CHF by X-ray although some increase in volume
   overload after fluids today.
   .
   # Shock:   patient with recent admission for c. difficilie coliits and
   has been on abx recently.  Ddx for sepis most likely urinary versus
   intrabdominal source vs. line sepsis.  She does have some LLQ
   tenderness on exam.  Given Echo findings unclear what component
   cardiogenic shock may play in presentation with also evidence for
   adrenal insufficiency given inadequate response to [**Last Name (un) 45**] stim
   yesterday.  Likely multifactorial with urosepsis precipitating shock in
   patient with newly depressed EF.
   - Continue vanc/zosyn/flagyl, and wean levophed as tolerated.
   - check stool culture (c. diff)
 not sent yet
   - Urine culture, sputum culture, blood culture pending
   - CT abd/pelvis to eval for colitis -> need to give IV contrast and so
   need access.
   - IVF and levophed as needed to keep MAP >65 (difficult to get CVP, fem
   line)
 will discuss change from levophed to dobutamine or dopamine for
   pressure support.
   - broad spectrum abx and will cover broadly until micro data confirm
   sensitivity of organism.
   - Will cover with vanc (OSH PICC in place) + zosyn (recent Icu
   admission) + IV flagyl for recent c. diff
   - [**Last Name (un) 45**] stim -> low so would give steroids.
   - fingersticks for euglycemic control
   ..
   # CAD: Recent large anterior infarct, with EF 20-25%.
   - Aspirin 81mg daily
 consider increasing to 325mg daily
   - Start statin
 lipitor 80mg daily, check lipid panel
   - Add ACE/B-blocker once pressure allows.
   .
   # A fib:  rate controlled for now.  Supratherapeutic INR.  Continue
   coumadin on discharge.
   .
   # DVT: Supratherapeutic INR, hold anticoagulation until therapeutic
   [**12-23**].
   # Coagulopathy: Supratherapetic INR (on coumadin at home) hold coumadin
   for now.  Will check DIC labs.
   # post pharyngeal laceration:  CT showing free air but patent airway.
   # transaminitis: may be from hypotension would follow daily.
   .
   # Access: will need to re-site femoral line, once coagulopathy is
   reversed.  Most likely option is IJ under ultrasound.  A-line
   yesterday, will need peripheral IV or power-PICC for CT Abdomen/Pelvis
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2109-3-26**] 08:00 AM
   Arterial Line - [**2109-3-26**] 01:10 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Supratherapeutic INR
   Stress ulcer: famotidine
   VAP:  chlorhexadine
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: FULL
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old female with a history of COPD, CAD, a fib, lung cancer, and recent cardiac event, currently intubated and in septic shock. She has a recent large anterior infarct with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. She has developed respiratory failure, shock, and coagulopathy. She has a history of c. difficile colitis and is on antibiotics. She has a pharyngeal laceration and a recent PICC line in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to septic shock and may require further management with pressure support therapy.
2. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's recent cardiac event and depressed ejection fraction may contribute to cardiogenic shock, which may require further management with dobutamine or dopamine.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's supratherapeutic INR and history of c. difficile colitis may indicate a risk of bleeding, which may require further management with platelet transfusions and anticoagulation reversal.
4. DVT: The patient's recent PICC line and history of immobility may increase her risk of developing DVT, which may require further management with anticoagulation therapy.
5. Infection: The patient's septic shock and history of c. difficile colitis may indicate a risk of further infection, which may require further management with antibiotics and antifungal therapy.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient's recent cardiac event and depressed ejection fraction may increase her risk of further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and heart failure.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's septic shock and history of c. difficile colitis may increase her risk of neurological complications, such as seizures and encephalopathy.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as needed.
2. Consider transferring the patient to a cardiac intensive care unit for further management of her cardiac complications.
3. Monitor the patient's coagulation status and adjust anticoagulation therapy as needed.
4. Consider re-siting the femoral line to an internal jugular vein under ultrasound guidance.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte and acid-base status and adjust therapy as needed.
6. Consider adding stress ulcer prophylaxis to the patient's medication regimen.
7. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust therapy as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU patient with a complex medical history. The patient has a significant cardiac condition, with a recent anterior infarct and severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, resulting in a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 20-25%. The patient also has a thoracic surgery consult due to subcutaneous emphysema and inability to place both nasogastric tube (NGT) and orogastric tube (OGT).

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's cardiovascular status is concerning, with evidence of focal deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right cephalic vein surrounding an indwelling peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC). The patient has also been administered norepinephrine to support blood pressure.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T levels, indicating cardiac injury. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are mildly elevated, and the patient has a mild elevation in lactate levels.

The patient's imaging studies show extensive subcutaneous emphysema, predominantly in the right neck, and moderate bilateral pleural effusions and atelectasis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction and reduced LVEF put them at risk for cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock, arrhythmias, and heart failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but they are at risk for respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), respiratory failure, and hypoxia.
3. Thrombotic complications: The patient's evidence of focal DVT and elevated D-dimer levels put them at risk for further thrombotic complications, such as pulmonary embolism (PE) and stroke.
4. Infection complications: The patient's subcutaneous emphysema and inability to place NGT and OGT increase their risk for infection, such as pneumonia, sepsis, and wound infections.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's inability to eat and their prolonged use of mechanical ventilation put them at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, ileus, and malnutrition.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address their complex medical condition and prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 45-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of cardiomyopathy, other, likely resulting from septic shock. She has a history of c. difficile colitis and has been on antibiotics recently. She has also been diagnosed with acute respiratory failure, acute episode of sob at rehab concerning for PNA versus PE versus CHF, and has a PICC line in place.

The patient's physical examination reveals a well-nourished, overweight/obese individual with a temperature of 36.6°C (97.9°F), heart rate of 77 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 83/52 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100%. She has a tracheostomy tube in place and is receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 20.2 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 95 x 10^9/L. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a potassium level of 4.3 mEq/L. Her liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an alanine aminotransferase level of 76 IU/L and an aspartate aminotransferase level of 112 IU/L.

The patient's imaging studies show a moderate bilateral pleural effusion and atelectasis, as well as an extensive subcutaneous emphysema in the right neck. Her echocardiogram reveals severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with akinesis of the septum and anterior wall and severe hypokinesis of the rest of the segments.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of c. difficile colitis and has been on antibiotics recently, which increases her risk of developing sepsis.
2. Cardiomyopathy: The patient's cardiomyopathy is likely to worsen if she does not receive appropriate treatment.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if she does not receive mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's supratherapeutic INR increases her risk of bleeding.
5. Post-pharyngeal laceration: The patient's post-pharyngeal laceration may lead to further complications, such as infection or respiratory distress.
6. Transaminitis: The patient's transaminitis may worsen if she does not receive appropriate treatment.
7. Access: The patient's femoral line may need to be re-sited once her coagulopathy is reversed.
8. DVT: The patient's DVT may worsen if she does not receive appropriate treatment.
9. Stress ulcer: The patient's stress ulcer may worsen if she does not receive appropriate treatment.
10. VAP: The patient's VAP may worsen if she does not receive appropriate treatment.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old female with a complex medical history, including COPD, CAD, a fib, lung cancer, and recent cardiac event. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation for respiratory distress and septic shock.

The patient's recent cardiac event is characterized by a large anterior infarct, with an EF of 20-25%. This is likely contributing to her cardiogenic shock. The patient's echocardiogram shows severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with akinesis of the septum and anterior wall and severe hypokinesis of the rest of the segments.

The patient's respiratory status is complicated by her COPD, and she requires intubation and mechanical ventilation. Her ABG results are excellent, but she is at risk for respiratory failure due to her underlying lung disease and the potential for further cardiac compromise.

The patient's septic shock is likely multifactorial, with a possible urinary source, intrabdominal source, or line sepsis. Her blood cultures, urine culture, and sputum culture are pending, and she is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient's coagulopathy is supratherapeutic, and her INR is elevated. She has a history of a fib and is on coumadin, which may be contributing to her coagulopathy. Her D-dimer is elevated, and she has evidence of focal DVT in the right cephalic vein.

The patient's access is complicated, with a multi-lumen line and an arterial line in place. She requires re-siting of her femoral line once her coagulopathy is reversed, and a peripheral IV or power- PICC may be necessary for her CT abdomen/pelvis.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's underlying lung disease and cardiogenic shock put her at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's recent cardiac event and underlying CAD may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is likely multifactorial, and she may develop further complications if her underlying sepsis is not adequately treated.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's supratherapeutic INR and elevated D-dimer put her at risk for bleeding complications.
5. DVT: The patient's evidence of focal DVT in the right cephalic vein may lead to further clotting complications if not adequately treated.
6. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's recent cardiac event and cardiogenic shock put her at risk for cardiac tamponade.
7. Renal failure: The patient's septic shock and cardiogenic shock may lead to renal failure if not adequately treated.
8. Hepatic failure: The patient's transaminitis may be a sign of underlying liver dysfunction, which may worsen if not adequately treated.

In summary, the patient is a complex medical case with multiple comorbidities and potential complications. Close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications and optimize her care.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old female with a complex medical history, including COPD, CAD, atrial fibrillation, lung cancer, and a recent large anterior infarct. She is currently in the ICU with respiratory distress and septic shock.

The patient's condition is complicated by several factors, including:

1. Cardiomyopathy: The patient has a recent large anterior infarct with an ejection fraction of 20-25%, which is a significant decrease from her baseline.
2. Septic shock: The patient has evidence of septic shock, with a blood pressure of 83/52 mmHg and a heart rate of 77 beats per minute. She has also received broad-spectrum antibiotics and is being treated with vasopressors.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and has a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute. She has a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 365, which suggests that she has significant hypoxemia.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a supratherapeutic INR, which may be related to her recent cardiac event or her anticoagulation therapy.
5. DVT: The patient has evidence of a focal DVT in the right cephalic vein surrounding an indwelling PICC line.
6. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be related to her hypotension or her recent cardiac event.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Cardiovascular support: The patient is being treated with vasopressors and is receiving oxygen therapy to maintain her blood pressure and oxygenation.
2. Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation to support her respiratory function.
3. Antibiotic therapy: The patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat her septic shock and potential urinary or intrabdominal source of sepsis.
4. DVT prophylaxis: The patient is being treated with anticoagulation therapy to prevent further thrombotic events.
5. Coagulopathy management: The patient's coagulopathy is being managed with platelet transfusions and anticoagulation therapy.
6. Nutrition and glycemic control: The patient is receiving nutrition support and is being monitored for hyperglycemia.
7. Access: The patient's access is being managed with a multi-lumen catheter and an arterial line.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical issues. They were admitted with a pharyngeal tear, which is currently stable, and a cuff leak, which requires discussion with the intensivist for a potential tube change. The patient's hemodynamics are likely mixed, with sepsis being a dominant factor, and they are still fluid responsive. The patient has a new ant wall motion abnormality, which is likely due to an event in the past three weeks, but no acute event is suspected.

The patient has a coagulopathy, which requires reversal, and they are at risk for bleeding due to potential procedures. They have a history of atrial fibrillation and were previously anticoagulated, but now need reversal. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and D-dimer, indicating sepsis. They also have abnormal liver enzymes and coagulation studies.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with mechanical ventilation and pressor support required. Their airway is compromised, with a cuff leak and a need for repositioning of the endotracheal tube. The patient's kidney function is impaired, with oliguria and elevated creatinine.

The patient's medical history is significant for sepsis, presumed pneumonia, and a PICC infection, which is now resolved. They have a history of atrial fibrillation and were previously anticoagulated.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
2. Bleeding complications due to coagulopathy and potential procedures.
3. Airway compromise due to cuff leak and need for repositioning of the endotracheal tube.
4. Worsening of liver and kidney function.
5. Development of septic shock.
6. Increased risk of pneumonia and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
7. Need for invasive procedures, such as central line placement and arterial line management, which can increase the risk of complications.

To address these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal status. The team should also consider the patient's goals of care and quality of life issues, as discussed during the family meeting.

The ventilator settings include a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory rate of 12, and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. The patient's SpO2 is 100%, and ABG results indicate a pH of 7.40, PaO2 of 365, and PaCO2 of 37.
2. Cardiovascular status: The patient has atrial fibrillation, and their heart rate is irregular. Their blood pressure is 83/53 mmHg, and their cardiac output is likely impaired due to sepsis.
3. Renal function: The patient's creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL, indicating mild kidney dysfunction. Their blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is not provided, but it is likely elevated due to dehydration and sepsis.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a prolonged PT and PTT, indicating a bleeding diathesis. They are also receiving anticoagulation therapy for atrial fibrillation, which may contribute to their coagulopathy.
5. Infection: The patient has a pharyngeal tear and is at risk for aspiration. They also have a history of sepsis, which may be related to their PICC infection.
6. Nutrition: The patient is NPO and requires total parenteral nutrition (TPN), but they only have femoral access, which may be challenging to use for TPN.
7. Glycemic control: The patient's glucose level is 152 mg/dL, which is slightly elevated. They require close monitoring of their glucose levels to prevent hyperglycemia.
8. Hemodynamics: The patient is fluid responsive, indicating that they may have a mixed picture of sepsis and cardiac dysfunction. They are receiving norepinephrine to support their blood pressure.
9. New ant wall motion abnormality: The patient has a new echo abnormality indicating reduced wall motion, which may be related to a recent event or chronic condition.
10. Coagulopathy: The patient has a history of bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding due to their coagulopathy and anticoagulation therapy.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and they may require further interventions to improve their oxygenation and ventilation.
* Cardiovascular collapse: The patient's cardiac output is likely impaired, and they may be at risk for cardiovascular collapse if their blood pressure drops further.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is mildly elevated, and they may be at risk for further kidney dysfunction if their fluid status is not managed carefully.
* Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and anticoagulation therapy make them at risk for bleeding, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly.
* Infection: The patient has a history of sepsis and may be at risk for further infection if their wound is not properly managed.
* Malnutrition: The patient's NPO status and limited access for TPN make them at risk for malnutrition, which can further compromise their immune function and overall health.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with multiple comorbidities. The patient's condition is complex, and several medical complications can arise.

1. Respiratory Complications: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a high FiO2 (40%) and PEEP (5 cmH2O), which may lead to respiratory acidosis and hypoxemia. The patient's PaO2/FiO2 ratio is 365, indicating a moderate degree of hypoxemia.
2. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation, and their hemodynamic status is likely affected by sepsis. The patient is receiving norepinephrine, which may exacerbate cardiac complications. The patient's cardiac enzymes (CK, CKMB, Troponin-T) are elevated, indicating possible cardiac injury.
3. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status is not well-assessed due to the lack of documentation. However, the patient's electrolyte levels (sodium, potassium, magnesium, and phosphate) are abnormal, which may indicate neurological complications.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has a pharyngeal tear and is at risk of aspiration. The patient's abdominal exam is reassuring, but the patient has a history of abdominal pain and diarrhea.
5. Hematological Complications: The patient has a coagulopathy, which may be exacerbated by their anticoagulation therapy. The patient's platelet count is low, and their INR is elevated.
6. Infection Complications: The patient has a history of sepsis and has received antibiotics. The patient's blood cultures are positive for GPC, and the patient has a PICC line infection that has been treated. The patient is at risk of developing further infections, particularly ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
7. Renal Complications: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating possible renal dysfunction.
8. Nutritional Complications: The patient's nutritional status is not well-documented, but the patient is receiving nutrition support. The patient's glycemic control is not well-monitored, and the patient's glucose levels are elevated.

In conclusion, the patient is at high risk of developing multiple medical complications, including respiratory, cardiovascular, neurological, gastrointestinal, hematological, infection-related, renal, and nutritional complications. Close monitoring and management of these complications are crucial to improve the patient's outcome.

   79F with COPD, CAD, a fib, lung cancer, now with respiratory distress

 Likely resulting from septic shock (below).

   infiltrate on the CXR.

   awaiting AM RISBI.  Probably could tolerate pressure support trial
   today but given complicated intubation may be preferable to wait until
   swelling resolves so as not to loose airway.
   - Nebs given history of COPD
   - No e/o significant CHF by X-ray although some increase in volume
   overload after fluids today.
   .

   will try pressure support today.  Trauma of intubation may necessitate
   trach or extended intubation given swelling.
   - Cuff leak: Slow, continue to monitor.  Consider change over wire
   discuss with thoracics
   - ET tube migrating distally despite frequent repositioning.
   .
   # Shock:   patient with recent admission for c. difficilie coliits and
   has been on abx recently.  Ddx for sepis most likely urinary versus
   intrabdominal source vs. line sepsis.  She does have some LLQ
   tenderness on exam.  Given Echo findings unclear what component
   cardiogenic shock may play in presentation with also evidence for
   adrenal insufficiency given inadequate response to [**Last Name (un) 45**] stim
   yesterday.  Likely multifactorial with urosepsis precipitating shock in
   patient with newly depressed EF.

 not sent yet

 will discuss change from levophed to dobutamine or dopamine for

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old female with a complex medical history, including cardiomyopathy, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), coronary artery disease (CAD), atrial fibrillation (A fib), and lung cancer. She was admitted to the ICU with shock, respiratory failure, and septicemia.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36°C (96.8°F)
* Heart rate: 72 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 108/65 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16 inspirations per minute (IPM)
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Central venous pressure (CVP): 24 mmHg

The patient has a history of recent cardiac event, with an estimated ejection fraction (EF) of 20-25%. She has also had a large anterior infarct and is at risk for cardiogenic shock.

The patient's respiratory status is complicated by COPD, and she requires mechanical ventilation. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.38, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 37 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 146 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 21.7 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.1 g/dL
* Platelet count (PLT): 421 x 10^9/L
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 112 mg/dL
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.0 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.09 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L

The patient has a positive blood culture for gram-positive cocci and a positive urine culture for gram-negative rods. She also has a sputum culture that is pending.

The patient's medical management includes:

* Antibiotics: vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and metronidazole
* Vasopressors: levophed and dobutamine
* Corticosteroids: 24-hour course
* H2 blockers: famotidine
* Stress ulcer prophylaxis: H2 blocker
* DVT prophylaxis: SQ heparin
* VAP prophylaxis: chlorhexidine

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Cardiogenic shock
* Respiratory failure
* Sepsis
* Urosepsis
* Intrabdominal sepsis
* Line sepsis
* Coagulopathy
* Transaminitis
* DVT
* Pulmonary embolism

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old female with a history of COPD, CAD, atrial fibrillation, lung cancer, and recent cardiac event. She was admitted with respiratory distress and septic shock. The patient has a complicated medical history, including a recent admission for c. difficile colitis, and has been on antibiotics recently. She has a recent large anterior infarct with an ejection fraction of 20-25%. The patient's condition is critical, with acute respiratory failure, cardiomyopathy, and shock.

24-hour events:

* Blood cultures were taken from the left arterial line.
* Bronchoscopy was performed, and the patient's trachea was secured with a tube.
* The patient's central line was attempted on the left internal jugular vein but was unable to be threaded due to a possible clot.
* The patient's blood pressure was managed with levophed, and she was weaned off the medication after receiving 4 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP).
* The patient's urine output remained low, and she developed frothy sputum and increasing work of breathing, which led to the administration of 10mg of IV lasix.
* The patient's hemoglobin level decreased to 25.6%, and her platelet count decreased to 211 K/uL.

Assessment and plan:

The patient is at high risk for respiratory failure, cardiomyopathy, and shock. The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to septic shock, and she requires intubation and mechanical ventilation. The patient's cardiomyopathy is likely due to a recent cardiac event, and she requires cardiac medications such as aspirin, statins, and beta-blockers. The patient's shock is likely multifactorial, with possible components of cardiogenic shock, septic shock, and adrenal insufficiency.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if not managed properly, leading to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
2. Cardiomyopathy: The patient's cardiomyopathy is likely to worsen if not managed properly, leading to heart failure, arrhythmias, and decreased cardiac output.
3. Shock: The patient's shock is likely to worsen if not managed properly, leading to organ failure, sepsis, and death.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy is likely to worsen if not managed properly, leading to bleeding, thrombosis, and organ failure.
5. Infection: The patient's infection is likely to worsen if not managed properly, leading to sepsis, organ failure, and death.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrhythmias are likely to worsen if not managed properly, leading to cardiac arrest and death.
7. Renal failure: The patient's renal failure is likely to worsen if not managed properly, leading to acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage renal disease.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and sedation.
2. Continue to manage the patient's cardiomyopathy with cardiac medications such as aspirin, statins, and beta-blockers.
3. Continue to manage the patient's shock with vasopressors and fluids.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's coagulopathy and bleeding.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's infection and sepsis.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider dialysis if necessary.

In summary, the patient is a high-risk patient with a complex medical history, including COPD, CAD, atrial fibrillation, lung cancer, and recent cardiac event. Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory distress and sepsis. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently on anticoagulation therapy. She has been diagnosed with a pharyngeal tear and is being treated with antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36°C, heart rate of 77 bpm, and blood pressure of 124/82 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100%. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 21.7 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 8.1 g/dL, and a platelet count of 421 x 10^9/L. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL.

The patient's chest x-ray shows bilateral pulmonary edema, and her blood cultures are positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus aureus.

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and pulmonary edema increase her risk of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to continue, and she may develop septic shock if not properly managed.
3. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and anticoagulation therapy increase her risk of cardiovascular complications, such as stroke or bleeding.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen if not properly managed, leading to bleeding complications.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's respiratory failure and sepsis may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's respiratory failure and sepsis may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures, coma, or death.

To mitigate these risks, the patient should be closely monitored and managed by a multidisciplinary team of healthcare professionals. This may include adjustments to her antibiotic therapy, anticoagulation therapy, and respiratory support, as well as close monitoring of her vital signs and laboratory results.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a pharyngeal tear, respiratory distress, and hemodynamic instability. The patient has undergone various interventions, including bronchoscopy, blood culture, and antibiotic administration. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36°C, heart rate of 77 bpm, and blood pressure of 124/82 mmHg. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a respiratory rate of 17 inspirations per minute. The patient's blood cultures have grown coag-negative Staphylococcus, and the urine culture has shown a high level of Gram-negative rods.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's blood cultures have grown coag-negative Staphylococcus, which may indicate sepsis. The patient's hemodynamic instability and respiratory distress may also be related to sepsis.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and the patient is receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate if the underlying cause of the respiratory distress is not addressed.
3. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's heart rhythm is atrial fibrillation, and the patient has a history of cardiac disease. The patient's cardiac status may deteriorate if the underlying cause of the atrial fibrillation is not addressed.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, which may increase the risk of bleeding. The patient's anticoagulation therapy may need to be adjusted to prevent bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient's urine culture has shown a high level of Gram-negative rods, which may indicate a urinary tract infection. The patient's blood cultures have also grown coag-negative Staphylococcus, which may indicate a blood-borne infection.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's abdominal examination is reassuring, but the patient's history of abdominal pain and diarrhea may indicate gastrointestinal complications.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status is unknown, and the patient may be at risk for neurological complications, such as stroke or seizures.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and respiratory status closely.
2. Adjust the patient's anticoagulation therapy as necessary to prevent bleeding.
3. Consider adding antibiotics to the patient's treatment regimen if the patient's infection is not responding to current therapy.
4. Consider performing a repeat echocardiogram to assess the patient's cardiac status.
5. Monitor the patient's urine output and electrolyte levels to prevent electrolyte imbalances.
6. Consider performing a repeat neurological examination to assess the patient's neurological status.

Summary:

The patient is a 62-inch tall, 74 kg individual admitted to the ICU with atrial fibrillation, respiratory distress, and sepsis. The patient has been receiving antibiotics, including Piperacillin/Tazobactam, Metronidazole, and Vancomycin, as well as other medications such as Midazolam, Furosemide, and Fentanyl. The patient has a central line, arterial line, and multi-lumen line inserted.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36°C, heart rate of 77 bpm, and blood pressure of 124/82 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 100%. The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and troponin levels, indicating ongoing sepsis. The patient's coagulation studies show elevated D-dimer and fibrinogen levels, suggesting disseminated intravascular coagulation. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, and the patient's albumin level is low, indicating malnutrition.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing sepsis is a significant concern, and the patient's laboratory results indicate that the sepsis is not resolving. The patient may require additional antibiotics or other treatments to manage the sepsis.
2. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): The patient's coagulation studies suggest that the patient may be experiencing DIC, which can lead to bleeding or clotting complications.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and the patient's oxygen saturation is dependent on mechanical ventilation. The patient may require additional respiratory support or oxygen therapy.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and elevated troponin levels suggest that the patient may be at risk for cardiac complications, including arrhythmias or heart failure.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's low albumin level and elevated liver enzymes suggest that the patient may be malnourished, which can increase the risk of complications and delay recovery.
6. Infection: The patient's urine culture and blood culture results indicate that the patient has a urinary tract infection and bacteremia. The patient may require additional antibiotics or other treatments to manage the infection.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and promote recovery.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress, sepsis, and cardiac issues. They have been intubated and are receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a history of pharyngeal tear, which is being managed with antibiotics and daily CT scans. They have also developed respiratory distress, which is being treated with diuresis and ABGs. The patient's hemodynamics are mixed, with sepsis initially dominating but now cardio-genic dominating. They have developed new ant wall motion abnormality, likely due to an event in the past three weeks. The patient has a coagulopathy and is being anticoagulated for atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and respiratory failure could worsen if not properly managed, leading to further decline in oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis could progress to septic shock if not adequately treated, leading to multi-organ failure and increased mortality.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac issues, including atrial fibrillation and new ant wall motion abnormality, could worsen if not managed properly, leading to cardiac arrest or cardiac failure.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy could increase the risk of bleeding complications, including intracranial hemorrhage, if not adequately managed.
5. Worsening of pharyngeal tear: The patient's pharyngeal tear could worsen if not properly managed, leading to further respiratory distress and potential airway compromise.
6. Intubation-related complications: The patient's intubation could lead to complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, respiratory failure, and airway damage.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's mixed hemodynamic picture could lead to cardiovascular instability, including hypotension, hypertension, or cardiac arrest, if not properly managed.
8. Increased risk of infection: The patient's compromised immune system and presence of invasive lines and devices could increase the risk of infection, including central line-associated bloodstream infections and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

 Likely resulting from septic shock (below).

   - issue regarding SQ emphysema has remained stable and low concern for
   esophageal injury

   - Nebs given history of COPD.

   cardiogenic shock may play in presentation with also evidence for
   adrenal insufficiency given inadequate response to [**Last Name (un) 45**] stim
   yesterday.  Likely multifactorial with urosepsis precipitating shock in

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiogenic shock: The patient has a history of cardiomyopathy, recent large anterior infarct, and newly depressed EF, which may contribute to cardiogenic shock.
2. Septic shock: The patient has a diagnosis of septic shock, which is likely multifactorial, with urosepsis precipitating shock in a patient with newly depressed EF.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated due to respiratory failure, which may be related to septic shock, pneumonia, or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient has a decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and increased serum creatinine, which may indicate acute kidney injury.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has received vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma (FFP) and has an international normalized ratio (INR) of 1.6, which may indicate coagulopathy.
6. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be related to hypotension, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.
7. Anemia: The patient has a low reticulocyte count, low hemoglobin, and elevated ferritin, which may indicate chronic disease with a component of iron deficiency.
8. DVT: The patient is at risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to immobility and may require prophylactic anticoagulation.
9. Line-related complications: The patient has multiple lines, including a central line, arterial line, and PICC line, which may be at risk for complications such as infection, bleeding, or thrombosis.
10. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of constipation and may be at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, or other complications.

To address these potential complications, the patient should receive close monitoring, aggressive treatment for septic shock, and management of underlying conditions such as cardiomyopathy, COPD, and anemia. Additionally, prophylactic measures such as DVT prophylaxis, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and VAP prophylaxis should be implemented.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old female with a complex medical history, including cardiomyopathy, COPD, CAD, atrial fibrillation, lung cancer, and recent admission for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) colitis.

The patient has experienced a recent cardiac event, with a depressed ejection fraction (EF) of 20-25%. She has also developed septic shock, likely due to urosepsis, and has been treated with antibiotics.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with acute respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation. The patient has also experienced an unplanned extubation, which required re-intubation.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of anemia, with a low reticulocyte count and ferritin level, suggesting chronic disease with iron deficiency. Her coagulation studies are abnormal, with a prolonged international normalized ratio (INR) and decreased platelet count.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Cardiovascular management: Aspirin, atorvastatin, and ACE inhibitor/B-blocker therapy.
2. Respiratory management: Mechanical ventilation, diuresis, and bronchodilators.
3. Infectious disease management: Antibiotics for sepsis, and further evaluation for urinary and intrabdominal sources of infection.
4. Hematological management: Blood transfusion and iron supplementation.
5. Thromboprophylaxis: Heparin gtt for DVT prophylaxis.
6. Stress ulcer prophylaxis: H2 blocker.
7. VAP prophylaxis: Chlorhexidine.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Cardiovascular complications: Cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory complications: Respiratory failure, pneumonia, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
3. Infectious complications: Sepsis, urinary tract infections, and intrabdominal infections.
4. Hematological complications: Anemia, bleeding, and thrombocytopenia.
5. Thrombotic complications: Deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and arterial thrombosis.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the medical plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old woman who is critically ill with respiratory failure, sepsis, and heart failure. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. The patient had an unplanned extubation at 01:48 PM on 03/28/2109, which was successfully managed without stridor, but with increased work of breathing. The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and cardiovascular medications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C (96.9°F), heart rate of 82 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 110/68 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 100%. The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation, and she has a central venous pressure of 25.8 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of sepsis, with a white blood cell count of 14.5 K/μL, and a lactate level of 0.7 mmol/L. Her blood cultures are pending, but the sputum culture has grown yeast. The patient's cardiac enzymes are normal, and her troponin level is 0.09 ng/mL.

The patient's plan includes continuing mechanical ventilation, converting from assist-control to pressure support ventilation, and assessing her ability to tolerate this mode. She will also be weaned off pressure support ventilation and tried for spontaneous breathing trials in the morning if her oxygenation and ventilation are adequate. The patient will also be continued on diuretics to manage her fluid balance and will be monitored for signs of sepsis and heart failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen if she is unable to tolerate the pressure support ventilation mode or if she experiences further respiratory distress.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis can progress if she is not adequately treated with antibiotics and other supportive measures.
3. Heart failure: The patient's heart failure can worsen if she is not adequately managed with diuretics and other cardiovascular medications.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy can increase her risk of bleeding if she is not adequately anticoagulated.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional deficiencies can worsen if she is not receiving adequate nutrition and hydration.
6. Infection: The patient's infection can spread to other parts of her body if she is not adequately treated with antibiotics and other supportive measures.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrhythmias can worsen if she is not adequately managed with anti-arrhythmic medications and other cardiovascular medications.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to identify any potential complications early and intervene promptly to prevent them from worsening.

The patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history, currently admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for close monitoring and treatment. The patient has undergone an unplanned extubation, which has led to respiratory distress, and is currently being managed with assisted ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.9°C (96.6°F), heart rate of 82 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 110/68 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100%, and they are receiving supplemental oxygen via the ventilator.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and their cardiac rhythm is currently irregular. They have a Swan-Ganz catheter in place, which is monitoring their hemodynamic status.

The patient's laboratory results indicate that they have a white blood cell count of 14.5 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 7.9 g/dL, and a platelet count of 26 x 10^9/L. Their liver enzymes are mildly elevated, and their renal function is within normal limits.

The patient's medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), congestive heart failure (CHF), and atrial fibrillation. They have a history of pneumonia, and their sputum culture has grown yeast.

The patient's current medications include antibiotics, anticoagulants, and diuretics. They are also receiving vasopressors to support their blood pressure.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress can lead to respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and CHF makes them susceptible to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, or cardiogenic shock.
3. Sepsis: The patient's history of pneumonia and the presence of yeast in their sputum culture make them at risk for developing sepsis.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's anticoagulation therapy can increase their risk of bleeding complications.
5. Kidney injury: The patient's history of CHF and the use of diuretics can increase their risk of kidney injury.
6. Liver dysfunction: The patient's mildly elevated liver enzymes can indicate liver dysfunction, which can be a sign of a more severe underlying condition.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's nutritional status is at risk due to their inability to eat and their need for parenteral nutrition.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history and multiple comorbidities. They require close monitoring and treatment in the ICU to manage their respiratory distress, cardiac status, and other potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual who has been admitted to the ICU. The patient had an unplanned extubation at 01:48 PM on [**2109-3-28**], which was managed without stridor but with increased work of breathing. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C, heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 110/68 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with an oxygen saturation of 100% and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and creatinine levels, indicating potential inflammation and kidney damage. The patient's blood cultures are positive for yeast, and the urine culture is pending. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's medications include antibiotics, such as vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and cefipime, as well as diuretics, such as furosemide, and sedatives, such as midazolam. The patient is also receiving nutrition through a pulmonary tube.

The patient's physical examination is notable for the presence of an endotracheal tube and a nasogastric tube. The patient's abdomen is soft, and the skin is not assessed due to the patient's critical condition.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's unplanned extubation and increased work of breathing may indicate respiratory failure, which can lead to further complications, such as hypoxia and respiratory acidosis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's positive blood culture for yeast and elevated white blood cell count may indicate sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Kidney damage: The patient's elevated creatinine levels may indicate kidney damage, which can lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
4. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's slightly elevated potassium level may indicate an electrolyte imbalance, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.
5. Infection: The patient's positive urine culture and pending results may indicate a urinary tract infection, which can lead to further complications, such as sepsis and kidney damage.
6. VAP: The patient's presence in the ICU and use of mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which can lead to further complications, such as sepsis and death.
7. DVT: The patient's presence in the ICU and immobility may increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to further complications, such as pulmonary embolism and death.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual who requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications. The patient's medical team should continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status, and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 79-year-old female with a complex medical history, including COPD, CAD, atrial fibrillation, lung cancer, and a recent large anterior infarct with an estimated ejection fraction of 20-25%. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation for respiratory failure. She has a history of septic shock and is being treated with antibiotics. The patient has a multifactorial presentation, with possible sources of sepsis including urinary, intrabdominal, and line-related infections.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and neutrophil percentage, indicating an inflammatory response
* Elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, suggesting kidney dysfunction
* Elevated troponin-T levels, indicating cardiac injury
* Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels, suggesting liver dysfunction
* Low albumin and hemoglobin levels, indicating malnutrition and anemia

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Bilateral atelectasis and pleural effusion on chest X-ray
* Coag-negative Staphylococcus aureus (CoNS) isolated from blood cultures
* Yeast isolated from sputum

The patient's medical plan includes:

* Continuing antibiotics for septic shock
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis and adjusting treatment as needed
* Managing cardiac status with aspirin, atorvastatin, and potentially ACE/B-blocker
* Monitoring for and treating potential complications such as DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Considering iron supplementation for anemia
* Monitoring for and treating potential liver and kidney dysfunction

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis and septic shock
* Cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and cardiac arrest
* Respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Hepatic and renal dysfunction
* Anemia and bleeding
* DVT and pulmonary embolism
* Stress ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding
* VAP and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)

I will continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old female with a complex medical history, including COPD, CAD, atrial fibrillation, lung cancer, and recent cardiac event. The patient is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure, septic shock, and cardiomyopathy.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 99%. The patient is intubated and on CPAP/PSV mode with a tidal volume of 450 mL. The patient's lung bases show bilateral atelectasis and pleural effusion.

The patient's cardiac status is concerning, with a recent large anterior infarct and an estimated ejection fraction of 20-25%. The patient is on aspirin, atorvastatin, and has a pacemaker.

The patient's blood cultures are positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and the urine culture is growing >100,000 GNR, which is sensitive to cefepime. The patient's white blood cell count is 10.4, and the platelet count is 315.

The patient's electrolytes are slightly abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.0 mEq/L and a magnesium level of 1.9 mg/dL. The patient's liver enzymes are mildly elevated, with an AST level of 31 and an ALT level of 24.

The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease with a component of iron deficiency. The patient's stool culture is negative for C. difficile.

The patient's DVT prophylaxis includes heparin gtt, and the patient is on stress ulcer prophylaxis with a H2 blocker.

The patient's code status is DNR, and the patient's disposition is to remain in the ICU.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's recent cardiac event and decreased ejection fraction make them at risk for further cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory failure and intubation make them at risk for further respiratory complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, respiratory failure, and respiratory arrest.
3. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock and positive blood cultures make them at risk for further sepsis and septic shock.
4. Bleeding complications: The patient's anemia and recent cardiac event make them at risk for bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.
5. Thrombotic complications: The patient's DVT prophylaxis and recent cardiac event make them at risk for thrombotic complications, such as pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's recent C. difficile infection and gastrointestinal symptoms make them at risk for further gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's recent cardiac event and decreased ejection fraction make them at risk for neurological complications, such as stroke, transient ischemic attack, and seizures.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old female with a history of COPD, CAD, and small cell lung cancer, admitted to the ICU with airway trauma, respiratory failure, and shock. She was found to have a retropharyngeal swelling and soft tissue laceration, which was managed with a LMA and later intubation. She required pressors for hypotension and was initially septic with a newly decreased ejection fraction. She was treated with antibiotics, diuretics, and anticoagulation. She developed volume overload, which was managed with gentle diuresis. She also had leukocytosis, which was attributed to steroids and stress. She had a UTI, which was treated with Zosyn, and a CX growing Klebsiella. She had a code status of DNR.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely to worsen if she develops further lung injury or if her respiratory function is not adequately supported.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen if she develops further infection or if her immune system is not adequately supported.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac failure is likely to worsen if she develops further cardiac injury or if her cardiac function is not adequately supported.
4. Volume overload: The patient's volume overload is likely to worsen if she develops further fluid accumulation or if her diuretic therapy is not adequately managed.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is likely to worsen if she develops further infection or if her immune system is not adequately supported.
6. UTI: The patient's UTI is likely to worsen if it is not adequately treated or if the patient develops further infection.
7. Retropharyngeal abscess or mediastinitis: The patient's retropharyngeal swelling and soft tissue laceration are potential sites for abscess or mediastinitis, which could lead to further complications.
8. C diff colitis: The patient's recent admission for C diff colitis is a potential source of further infection.
9. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac history and recent cardiac events make her susceptible to further cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, or cardiac failure.

She was admitted to the ICU with airway trauma, respiratory failure, and shock. The patient had failed attempts at intubation due to retropharyngeal trauma and soft tissue laceration, and was eventually intubated via a laryngeal mask airway (LMA). She was transferred to the ICU, where she was found to have hypothermia and shock.

The patient has been treated with multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin, zosyn, and cefepime, and has received several liters of IV fluids. She has also been treated with lasix for volume overload and has been diuresing well. The patient's cardiac status is complicated, with a new echocardiogram showing left ventricular dysfunction (EF 20-25%) and a possible cardiogenic component to her shock.

The patient has been on a heparin drip for atrial fibrillation and has had a PICC line placed. She has also had a midline catheter placed and has been receiving prophylactic antibiotics.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient has been treated for septic shock, but the source of the infection is still unclear. Further investigation is needed to identify the source of the infection and to ensure that it is adequately treated.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is complex, with a new echocardiogram showing left ventricular dysfunction. Further cardiac evaluation is needed to determine the extent of the cardiac damage and to develop a plan for cardiac management.
3. Respiratory complications: The patient is intubated and has been treated for respiratory failure. Further respiratory evaluation is needed to determine the extent of the respiratory damage and to develop a plan for respiratory management.
4. Renal complications: The patient has been treated with lasix for volume overload and has been diuresing well. However, further renal evaluation is needed to determine the extent of the renal damage and to develop a plan for renal management.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient has been treated with heparin for atrial fibrillation, and has had a PICC line placed. Further evaluation is needed to determine the extent of the bleeding risk and to develop a plan for bleeding management.

Overall, the patient's medical status is complex and requires close monitoring and management. Further evaluation and treatment are needed to address the patient's various medical complications and to ensure that she receives the best possible care.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old female with a history of COPD, CAD, and small cell lung cancer, who presented to the ICU with airway trauma, respiratory failure, and shock. She was intubated and mechanically ventilated, and was initially hypotensive requiring pressors, likely due to a combination of septic and cardiogenic components. She has since been weaned off pressors and is currently volume overloaded. The patient has a pharyngeal tear, which is stable, and is being managed with diuresis and close monitoring of ABGs. Her hemodynamics are stable, but she has decreased left ventricular ejection fraction and is at risk for heart failure. She also has leukocytosis, which may be related to a urinary tract infection (UTI) or other underlying conditions. The patient has a DNR code status and is being managed in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she is at risk for further deterioration. Close monitoring of her oxygenation and ventilation is necessary.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely related to her UTI, and she may be at risk for further complications if not adequately treated.
3. Heart failure: The patient's decreased left ventricular ejection fraction and risk of heart failure make her at risk for further cardiac complications.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be related to a UTI or other underlying conditions, and close monitoring is necessary to determine the cause and ensure appropriate treatment.
5. Infection: The patient's D-dimer level is elevated, which may indicate an underlying infection. Close monitoring of her infection markers and imaging studies is necessary to determine the cause and ensure appropriate treatment.
6. Thromboembolic events: The patient is at risk for thromboembolic events due to her immobility and underlying medical conditions. Close monitoring and prophylaxis are necessary to prevent these complications.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of bleeding and her current use of anticoagulation therapy make her at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding. Close monitoring and prophylaxis are necessary to prevent these complications.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   79F with COPD, CAD, a fib, lung cancer, now with respiratory distress
   and septic shock now with clear evidence of recent cardiac event.
   .
   # Respiratory failure
 Likely resulting from septic shock (below) with
   component of CHF.  Self extubated yesterday but did not tolerate and
   had to be reintubated.  Today, RISBI again good, and could likely be
   extubated.  Has diuresed a bit since self extubating but would like to
   further optimize prior to re-attempting given patient has now had
   several intubation attempts.
   - Intubated after a complicated course at OSH (pharyngeal laceration).
   - tolerating pressure support, will wean support settings.  Get ABG on
   pressure support
   - issue regarding SQ emphysema has remained stable and low concern for
   esophageal injury
   - pharyngeal edema stable
   - Nebs given history of COPD.
   .
   # Shock:   patient with recent admission for c. difficilie coliits and
   has been on abx recently.  Ddx for sepis most likely urinary versus
   intrabdominal source vs. line sepsis.  She did  have some LLQ
   tenderness on exam.  Given Echo findings unclear what component
   cardiogenic shock may play in presentation with also evidence for
   adrenal insufficiency given inadequate response to [**Last Name (un) 45**] stim
   yesterday.  Likely multifactorial with urosepsis precipitating shock in
   patient with newly depressed EF.
   - off pressors, switched zosyn to cefepime while awaiting speciation
   urine cx, d/c vanco and flagyl, d/w ID, C.diff negative times 2
 but
   will restart cefepime given sensitivities on Urine Culture.
   - check stool culture (c. diff)
 negative times 2
   - Urine culture growing >100,000 GNR, -- Klebsiella Pneumoniae
   sensitive to cefepime.
   - SCn from blood cx, likely contaminant, f/u cx ngtd thus far, continue
   vanco for now
   - d/c steroids
   - goal diuresis of 500cc today.
   .
   # CAD: Recent large anterior infarct, with EF 20-25%.
   - Aspirin 325mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Add ACE/B-blocker once pressure allows.
   .
   # A fib:  rate controlled for now.  Follow INR daily, 1.3, received vit
   K. PPM interrogated by EP, device working well, place on heparin gtt
   .
   #  Anemia- retic count low, % sat <25, ferritin >400 in setting stress
   response, iron 43, all this most suggestive of chronic disease with
   component iron deficiency, would add iron supplementation. stools guiac
   negative thus far
   - 1 Unit PRBC yesterday given CAD, although overloaded, risk vs.
   benefit
   .
   # DVT: Received Vit K and FFP o/n, INR 1.3, place on heparin gtt
   .
   # Transaminitis: may be from hypotension would follow daily. Have
   normalized
   .
   # A-Line: self d
d yesterday.  Held pressure for 2 hours.  No e/o
   compartment syndrome at this time but will continue to monitor.
   .
   # Access: will attempt PICC line placement, if unsuccessful will need
   LIJ, difficulty in regards to pacer wires, thrombus, prior PICC on left
   side, t o be done in IR
   ICU Care

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old female with a complex medical history, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), coronary artery disease (CAD), atrial fibrillation (AF), lung cancer, and recent cardiac event. She was admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress and septic shock, which is likely multifactorial in origin.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: She is intubated and receiving pressure support ventilation, with a recent respiratory index score (RSBI) of 32, indicating that she is likely to be extubated soon.
* Cardiovascular: She has a recent large anterior infarct, with an ejection fraction (EF) of 20-25%. She is receiving aspirin, atorvastatin, and is awaiting further management.
* Hematology: She has anemia, with a reticulocyte count low, hemoglobin (Hb) level of 8.2 g/dL, and ferritin level of 400. She is also receiving iron supplementation.
* Infection: She has a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae, which is resistant to cephalosporins. She is receiving treatment with cefepime and vancomycin.
* Coagulation: She has a prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and is receiving heparin therapy.
* Liver function: She has transaminitis, which may be related to hypotension or sepsis.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: Given her recent respiratory distress and septic shock, there is a risk of further respiratory failure, particularly if she is not extubated soon.
* Cardiovascular complications: Her recent cardiac event and depressed EF make her prone to further cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
* Infection: Her UTI is likely to be a source of ongoing sepsis, and there is a risk of further infections, particularly if her immune system is compromised.
* Bleeding: Her prolonged PT and aPTT, as well as her recent cardiac event, make her at risk of bleeding, particularly if she receives anticoagulant therapy.
* Organ dysfunction: Her anemia, transaminitis, and coagulopathy may indicate underlying organ dysfunction, which could worsen if not addressed.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, cardiovascular disease, infection, and organ dysfunction. She requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve her clinical outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of Klebsiella pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and septic shock. She is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has been on pressure support of 25 cmH2O.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 107 bpm, and blood pressure of 88/50 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 99% on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of sepsis, with a white blood cell count of 19.5 K/uL and a lactate level of 0.7 mmol/L. Her renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 25 mg/dL. Her liver function is also impaired, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 31 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 24 IU/L.

The patient's medication regimen includes zosyn, decadron, lasix, heparin, fentanyl, and ASA. She is also receiving tube feeds and regular insulin sliding scale for glycemic control.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis may lead to organ dysfunction, particularly in the kidneys, liver, and lungs.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and her PaO2/FiO2 ratio is not provided. She may be at risk for respiratory failure, particularly if her respiratory rate increases or her PaO2/FiO2 ratio decreases.
3. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation and septic shock may lead to cardiovascular instability, including hypotension and arrhythmias.
4. Renal failure: The patient's impaired renal function may progress to renal failure, which can be life-threatening.
5. Hepatic failure: The patient's impaired liver function may progress to hepatic failure, which can be life-threatening.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's sepsis may lead to neurological complications, including seizures, coma, and stroke.
7. Infection-related complications: The patient's infection may lead to complications such as abscesses, empyema, and meningitis.

Based on the patient's condition, it is recommended that she receive close monitoring and management in the ICU. She should be continued on mechanical ventilation and receive antibiotics and vasopressors as needed. Her medication regimen should be adjusted as necessary to manage her sepsis and organ dysfunction. She should also receive close monitoring of her renal and liver function, and her respiratory and cardiovascular status.

   79F with COPD, CAD, a fib, lung cancer, now with respiratory distress
   and septic shock now with clear evidence of recent cardiac event.
   .
   # Respiratory failure
 Likely resulting from septic shock (below) with
   component of CHF.  Successfully extubated today, CT showing no evidence
   of abscess and resolution of subcutaneous air.  With residual bilateral
   pleural effusions.
   - one more dose of decadron post intubation
   - Lasix to keep net negative -500 to 1L, gtt is held for large volume
   diuresis yesterday, giving lasix boluses today
   - Nebs given history of COPD.
   .
   # Klebsiella UTI: c/b by septic shock that has now resolved.
   -Zosyn to complete a 10 day course
   -Foley changed
   .
   # CAD: Recent large anterior infarct, with EF 20-25%.
   - Aspirin 325mg daily
   - Atorvastatin 80mg daily
   - Add ACE/B-blocker once pressure allows.
   .
   # A fib:  rate controlled for now.  Follow INR daily, 1.3, received vit
   K. PPM interrogated by EP, device working well, place on heparin gtt.
   -Will attempt to restart coumadin tomorrow
   .
   #  Anemia- retic count low, % sat <25, ferritin >400 in setting stress
   response, iron 43, all this most suggestive of chronic disease with
   component iron deficiency, would add iron supplementation. stools guiac
   negative thus far
   .
   # DVT: Received Vit K and FFP o/n, INR 1.3, place on heparin gtt
   .
   # Transaminitis: may be from hypotension would follow daily. Have
   normalized
